thread.title: Dodgy jobless numbers add up to RBA keeping rates low for longer
thread.title_full: Dodgy jobless numbers add up to RBA keeping rates low for longer | afr.com

author: Alan Mitchell
title: Dodgy jobless numbers add up to RBA keeping rates low for longer
text:
RBA Governor Glenn Stevens: don't expect another rate cut. by Alan Mitchell Another Reserve Bank statement on monetary policy, another deterioration in the economic outlook â€“ with a jump in the July unemployment rate to underscore the point.
But don't assume there will be another cut in the RBA's official cash rate.
For a start, the RBA has cut its forecast of the jobless rate despite the reported jump in the July unemployment rate to 6.3 per cent.
The bank's forecasters now expect the unemployment rate to remain around 6 per cent until the end of 2017.
Like most other economists, the RBA's forecasters clearly are taking the July number with a grain of salt.
The employment-to-population data, which abstracts from the problematic population numbers and the suspicious looking jump in the July female participation rate, shows there has been a steady improvement in the demand for labour.
Nevertheless, the economy's growth for the year to June 2016 has been trimmed by 0.5 of a percentage point mainly to reflect the weaker than expected growth in East Asia in the first half of 2015.
Something else is going on However, something else is going on. Lower than expected net immigration is cutting into the population growth rate.
That is likely to explain at least part of the improvement in the outlook for unemployment.
Less immigration and lower population growth means fewer people looking for work. And, as the bank explains, people of prime working age have made the biggest contribution to the change in net migration.
Lower net immigration also means less production and less demand for goods and services including houses, cars, furniture and all the other things people need to establish their homes in Australia.
How will that affect monetary policy? That will depend on the balance of the effects on demand and supply.
Well, despite the weaker economic growth outlook, the improvement in the outlook for the unemployment rate reduces the incentive for the RBA to cut rates, because the lower unemployment rate reduces the downward pressure on wage inflation.
As a technical assumption, the RBA has included the market's priced-in probability of a further cut in the official cash rate over the coming months. However, as the bank says, there also is a strong possibility that the gradual increase in the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy interest rates will see a further depreciation of the Australian dollar.
A more competitive exchange rate would reduce the need for a further easing of monetary policy in Australia.
